awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: A Biocultural Approach to Evaluating Psychosocial Stress Mediators in Vulnerable Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Disruptions in living arrangements create vulnerabilities for individuals whose day-to-day security is affected by displacement. Residence in temporary settlements presents a range of difficulties and vulnerabilities that may have long-term implications for health and resilience. How do displaced individuals negotiate control and regularity over their daily lives in the context of persistent uncertainty and limited availability of critical resources. This project, which trains a graduate student in anthropology in the methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, tests the hypothesis that displaced individuals regain control and enact resilience by engaging in routine activities. The importance of routine in helping people structure their daily lives, impart a sense of control and normalcy, and weather day-to-day stressors has been noted across research settings. Therefore, understanding the role of Routinized Social Practices (RSPs) on well-being is critical for developing programs that may improve long-term health outcomes among vulnerable populations affected by displacement. 

This multi-sited research will be conducted among vulnerable populations consisting of individuals negotiating displacement in the context of precarity. These populations face different specific contexts leading to displacement, opening the opportunity to discern both specific and general ways that RSPs may affect health and well-being. Specifically, this study will explore whether participation in RSPs is associated with healthier profiles for biological markers related to stress physiology and immune function. The researchers will also investigate the ways in which RSPs may help vulnerable individuals to maintain livable lives and negotiate their vulnerability following temporary residence in novel communities. The researchers will conduct surveys, collect information on RSPs, sources of stress, and lived experiences, and gather data on stress markers (cortisol, Epstein-Barr virus antibody levels, and blood pressure). Findings from this research will provide insights into the role of routine action in health and stress mediation by examining the extent to which RSPs make everyday life structured and regulated in transitional residential contexts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research, A Biocultural Approach to Evaluating Psychosocial Stress Mediators in Vulnerable Communities, examined the importance of mundane activities—termed Routinized Social Practices (RSPs)— in helping explain differences in the physiological profiles within vulnerable displaced communities. It explored how displaced people negotiate control and regularity in their daily lives amidst uncertainty and resource limitations. Using a mixed-methods approach, the overall research study integrated qualitative interviews, surveys, and stress-responsive biological markers (cortisol, Epstein-Barr virus antibodies, and blood pressure) to examine the relationship between RSPs, well-being, and physiology. Additionally, it added epigenetic markers to deepen understanding of the lasting impacts of psychosocial stress and trauma on refugee well-being.

 

The intellectual merit of this project lies in its advancement of knowledge at the intersection of forced migration, physiology, and social inequality, offering new insights into how displaced people use routine to navigate vulnerability and maintain dignity in transitional settings. This project has helped advance approaches to integrating sociocultural and biological data to explore the complex relationships between day-to-day social experiences and practices (RSPs) and stress mitigation in displaced communities across different geographical settings. 

 

The broader impacts of this research include enhancing scientific and educational infrastructure by training a graduate student and co-PI (Jankovic-Rankovic) in specialized laboratory techniques, such as those required for enzyme immunoassays, and helping facilitate her professional development through conference presentations and publications. This project also enhances science communication and public awareness, promotes education, and informs policies aimed at addressing health disparities in displaced communities and supporting their integration, underscoring its significance to broader societal challenges.

 

The project will generate a dataset combining ethnographic, survey, and biomarker information to serve as a resource for future interdisciplinary research initiatives and educational purposes. Findings will be disseminated through peer-reviewed publications and public outreach efforts. Continued partnerships with non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and displaced communities aim to enhance integration strategies and address health-related needs, fostering immediate and long-term societal benefits.
